vehicle.name: le PKW - car
vehicle.description: The VW Kuebelwagen was the German equivalent of the Jeep, though not as versatile. In BFTB, the Kuebelwagen is representative of the many different kinds of light cars, both of military and civilian production, which were fielded by the German army to motorize its troops, .

vehicle.name: SdKfz 2 - Kettenkrad
vehicle.description: The SdKfz 2 was developed as a cross-country alternative to the motorcycle with sidecar. It was widely used as a light transport and messenger vehicle.

vehicle.name: LKW 2 t - truck
vehicle.description: The German Army was always short on standardised transport. The 2t class of trucks included all lighter truck types with a loading capacity of about 2 tons. For BFTB, abstraction was made of the difference in trucks with and without cross-country capacities.

vehicle.name: LKW 3 t - truck
vehicle.description: Typified by the famous Opel Blitz model (shown) of which more than 70,000 were built, the 3 tonner was the mainstay of German military transport during the war. The 3t class of trucks included all medium truck types with a loading capacity of about 3 tons. For BFTB, abstraction was made of the difference in trucks with and without cross-country capacities.

vehicle.name: LKW 4.5 t - truck
vehicle.description: The German Army was always short on standardised transport. The 4.5t class of trucks included all heavier truck types with a loading capacity of about 4.5 tons. For BFTB, abstraction was made of the difference in trucks with and without cross-country capacities.

vehicle.name: LKW 6.5 t - truck
vehicle.description: The German Army was always short on standardised transport. The 6.5t class of trucks included all heavy truck types with a loading capacity of about 6.5 tons. For BFTB, abstraction was made of the difference in trucks with and without cross-country capacities.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 250/1 - Personnel
vehicle.description: By 1944, the Sd.Kfz. 250/1 was the standard troop carrying vehicle for the 2nd company of the armoured recon bn.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 250/8 - 7.5cm IG
vehicle.description: This combination of the 7.5cm KwK 37 L24 gun on the SdKfz 250 chassis first appeared in early 1943. They were issued to light reconnaissance companies.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 250/9 - 2cm gun
vehicle.description: The SPW 250/9 "Caesar" was a halftrack reconnaissance vehicle. It was an SPW 250 halftrack mounting a turret with a 20mm cannon, and was intended as the replacement for the SdKfz 222 armored car. The 250/9 was just what the German Army needed to combat the lack of roads on the Russian front. Though lightly armed and armored, it served as a recon vehicle on all fronts until the end of the war.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 250/10 - 3.7cm AT
vehicle.description: This combination of the 3.7cm PaK 36 on the SdKfz 250 chassis was used by platoon commanders in reconnaissance units for direct fire support. From late 1943 on, it no longer featured in the establishments.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 251/1 - Personnel
vehicle.description: The Sd.Kfz. 251 'mittlerer Schützenpanzerwagen' (m. SPW - medium APC) equipped the armoured Panzergrenadier companies from 1941 on. Extremely versatile, it was adapted to carry a variety of weapons. Some 16,000 were built. The final version, the Ausf. D, was reengineered to save production materials.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 251/2 - 8cm mortar
vehicle.description: The 8cm mortar was mounted into the SdKfz 251 and issued to the heavy platoon in armoured Panzergrenadier companies.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 251/9 - 7.5cm IG
vehicle.description: This combination of the old 7.5cm KwK 37 L/24 (from early model PzKfw IVs) on the SdKfz 251 chassis appeared in late 1942 in the Heavy companies of Panzer Grenadier battalions. It was commonly called the 'Stummel' (Stump).

vehicle.name: SdKfz 251/10 - 3.7cm AT
vehicle.description: This combination of the 3.7cm PaK 36 on the SdKfz 251 entered service in 1940. It was issued to platoon commanders to provide heavy fire support. From late 1943 on, it no longer featured in the establishments.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 251/17 - 2cm AA
vehicle.description: Different attempts were made to increase the AA defence of the mechanised Panzergrenadier battalion by mounting the 2cm Flak 38 onto the SdKfz 251 m.SPW. Among these was a Luftwaffe version with hinging side armour plates. The final and most widespread version, which entered service in the second half of 1944 mounted the gun in a small fully-rotating open-topped turret, called the 'Schwebelafette' ('gliding cradle'). Each mechanised Panzergrenadier Company was to field 7 such vehicles, but deliveries were irregular.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 10 - le ZgKw 1t
vehicle.description: The lightest of the unarmoured German half-tracks (with a towing capacity of 1 tonne) the SdKfz 10 entered service in 1938. Some 25,000 were built until 1944. It towed PaK and light flak guns and served as the chassis for the SdKfz 250 armoured half-track.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 11 - le ZgKw 3t
vehicle.description: The main prime mover for the FH 18 105mm howitzer and the PaK 40 anti-tank gun, the SdKfz 11 (3 tonne) entered service in 1938. It was an extremely versatile vehicle and remained in production throughout the war. Some 41,000 were built. It formed the basis for the ubiquitous SdKfz 251 armoured half-track and the Maultier self-propelled Nebelwerfer.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 7 - m ZgKw 8t
vehicle.description: Designed to tow 8 tonnes, the SdKfz 7 is best known as the prime mover for the famous 88mm flak gun. It entered service in 1934 and remained in production throughout the war. Nearly 8,000 were built.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 10/4 - 2cm Flak
vehicle.description: The 10/4 was the first German SP flak gun, using the 2cm Flak 38 on the SdKfz 10 half-track. 610 were built and were used by Wehrmacht and Luftwaffe flak units.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 6/2 - 3.7cm Flak
vehicle.description: An effective combination of the 3.7cm Flak 36 gun on the SdKfz 6 half-track. The 6/2 served mainly with Luftwaffe flak units. 339 were built until mid-1943. The gun was later mounted on the SdKfz 7 hlaf-track.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 7/1 - 2cm Flakvierling
vehicle.description: This was a highly effective combination of the four-barrelled 20mm Flakvierling gun on an SdKfz 7 half-track. As well flak defence it provided terrifying firepower in the direct fire role. 319 were built until October 1944.

vehicle.name: FlakPz IV Wirbelwind
vehicle.description: A deadly SP flak weapon, the Wirbelwind provided close flak defence for panzer regiments. It combined the ferocious four-barrelled 2cm Flakvierling gun on a Pz IV chassis. 86 were converted between July and November 1944.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 234/1 - 2cm gun
vehicle.description: The 234/1 was introduced in July 1944 and served in the Recon Battalions of Panzer and Panzer Grenadier divisions. It proved to be a very effective reconnaissance vehicle. About 200 were built.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 234/2 - Puma
vehicle.description: The Puma was a peculiar hybrid. Granted, for an armored car it had good armour and great speed, but its gun was heavier than was required for pure recon missions, while at the same time it was too light to provide effective AT and supporting fire. Only 101 were built from September 1943 to September 1944. Eventually priority was given to the SdKfz 234/1 and /3.

vehicle.name: StuG III G
vehicle.description: The StuG IIIG assault gun was based on previous versions of the PzKpfw III chassis. The original StuG III had been designed as an infantry support tank, but by 1943, StuGs were being used increasingly in an Anti-Tank role. This was made possible by the introduction of a longer barreled 75mm cannon and additional armor. The G model was the most common StuG built. Production started in late 1942 and continued through the end of the war, with some 7800 examples produced. In the game this unit also represents the earlier F and F/8 models, of which 359 and 354 were built respectively.

vehicle.name: Pz IV L/70 (V)
vehicle.description: The Panzer IV L/70, originally known as the Jagdpanzer IV Lang (long), but later renamed, combined the proven Pz IV chassis with the JagdPanzer IV superstructure and the 7.5cm L/70 gun of the Panther. Together with its low silhouette, this made for a very dangerous tank destroyer. Between May 1944 and March 1945 some 930 were built. The Pz IV/70 entered combat service in August 1944, within the Panzerjaeger-companies of the then newly created Panzer brigades, and then started replacing the Jagdpanzer IV within the Panzer divisions.

vehicle.name: PzKfw III Ausf M
vehicle.description: The Pz III was the main German medium tank at the start of the war. Regular upgrades kept it in combat till mid-1943. After that it was relegated to reserve and training units. Some 1,970 were built with the 5cm L60 gun.

vehicle.name: PzKfw IV Ausf J
vehicle.description: The Pz IV was the mainstay of the Pz divisions, serving (with regular improvement) throughout the war. The H and the J were the last models. Though old designs, they were superior to the Allied Shermans and Cromwells. 3,774 Ausf H were built from April 1943 to July 1944. This vehicle also represents part of the production run of the Pz IVG with the new gun and increased armor, plus the 1758 PzKpfw IVJ that were by far the most prevalent model in the Ardennes.

vehicle.name: PzKfw V Ausf G - Panther
vehicle.description: The best all-round tank of the war, combining excellent sloped armour with good mobility and the deadly 7.5cm L70 gun. Each Pz Division was meant have one Panther bn, but they were rarely up to strength. The Panther's major weakness was its complexity which affected its reliability. About 6,000 were built.

vehicle.name: PzKfw Tiger Ausf E - Tiger I
vehicle.description: Such was its reputation that "Tiger" became the generic term used by Allied troops for all heavy German armour. Introduced into combat in August 1942 it was a fearsome machine with heavy armour and the excellent 8.8cm gun, which was a variant of the infamous Flak gun. It suffered however from poor mobility and reliability. 1,354 were built.

vehicle.name: PzKfw Tiger Ausf B - Tiger II
vehicle.description: The King Tiger combined excellent sloped armour with the superb 8.8cm L71 gun which could destroy Shermans out to 3000m, but it was troubled by poor mobility and reliability. It entered combat service in June 1944, and 489 were built.

vehicle.name: 1/4 t truck 'Jeep'
vehicle.description: The Jeep is a legend. Eisenhower nominated it one of the three tools that enabled the Allies to win the war (along with the Dakota and landing craft). Cheap ($739 each), rugged and endlessly useful more than 653,000 were built during the war.

vehicle.name: Armored 1/4 t truck 'Jeep' - Vickers K Gun
vehicle.description: In Western Europe the SAS equipped its Jeeps with a twin mount of Vickers K Guns to the front and one to the back, often augmented with a Bren Gun, positioned next to the driver.

vehicle.name: Universal Carrier
vehicle.description: The Universal Carrier and it's variants was one of the most widely used armoured vehicles of World War II. Designated as "Carrier, Universal No.1 MkI" this vehicle featured a riveted hull with complete armour protection around the front and rear compartments. The third crew member sat in the rear compartment behind the driver.

vehicle.name: Cromwell IV
vehicle.description: The Cromwell was numerically the most important British cruiser tank of the war. By 1944 standards, however, it was a poor machine, and because of its poor design, could not be upgraded to match the late model PzKw IVs and Panthers.

vehicle.name: Cromwell VI - 95mm CS
vehicle.description: This was a close support variant of the Cromwell, with a 32 pdr (95mm) tank howitzer. They were issued to tank squadron HQs.

vehicle.name: Challenger (A30)
vehicle.description: This was the first British effort to improve on the Sherman. But the project suffered many delays and was overtaken by the Sherman Firefly program. Some Challengers were issued to armoured reconnaissance squadrons in late 1944 but it was a poor vehicle.

vehicle.name: Sherman Firefly VC
vehicle.description: The Sherman's weak gun and armour had a bad effect on unit morale. The British answer was to instal a 17 pdr gun. The first Fireflies were ready for D-Day and soon proved their worth. Because of a shortage of 17 pdrs, Fireflies were issued one per troop.

vehicle.name: Archer Mk I - 17pdr SP
vehicle.description: In early 1943 the 17 pdr was the first British or US gun in the same league as German 75mm weapons. Trouble was hardly any Brit or US tanks could mount the weapon. As a stop-gap the gun was mounted backwards on a Valentine chassis. The Archer appeared in combat from October 1944.

vehicle.name: Sexton - 25pdr SP
vehicle.description: This was an "Anglicised" version of the US M7 (Priest). It was developed in late 1942 and carried a 25 pdr (in place of the US 105mm howitzer) on a Ram chassis. The Sexton was issued to the Field Regiments of Armoured Divisions. 2,150 were built.

vehicle.name: AEC Mk III AC
vehicle.description: AEC Mk III Installed a British copy of the US M3 75 mm tank gun.4 Used mostly in Italy as fire support for armored car regiments, however a few were sent to Europe. Had electric powered traversing turret. Could be switched from 2 wheel to 4 wheel drive.4

vehicle.name: M8 - 37mm gun - .50 cal MG
vehicle.description: The M8 Light Armored Car served as the primary AFV in mechanized cavalry units, replacing the M3A1 Scout Car and the M2 Halftrack. Although it was lightly armored and undergunned, its crews liked its speed and the cross-country mobility provided by its light weight and 6x6 drive.

vehicle.name: White SC
vehicle.description: The M3A1 Scout Car was found mainly in mechanized cavalry troops of infantry and armored divisions, where its functions were to scout enemy positions, screen flanks and provide security. Some were used in tank destroyer battalions as well. Close to 21,000 were built, many of which were given to Allied nations through the Lend-Lease program.

vehicle.name: M3A1 HT - 50/30 cal MGs
vehicle.description: Like its German equivalents the M3 proved an extremely versatile and successful vehicle which was adapted for a broad range of reconnaissance, combat, transport and support roles. More than 41,000 were built until mid-1944.

vehicle.name: M4 Sherman - 75mm
vehicle.description: The Sherman was an attempt to redress the perceived inferiority of British and US tanks. With a poor gun and armour, the Sherman nevertheless had virtues of simplicity, reliability, speed and ruggedness. It was also cheap which enabled it to be built in vast numbers. These factors enabled British and US armoured forces finally to defeat the German Army in the West by attrition.

vehicle.name: M4 Sherman - 76mm
vehicle.description: Because U.S. Army doctrine called for tanks to be used as infantry support, Shermans were initially given 75mm guns. After clashes with Tigers and Panthers, it quickly became clear that a higher-velocity gun was needed. Originally, it was intended that one third of each Sherman unit be equipped with these improved models, but by VE Day, over half of all Shermans in the U.S. Army in Europe carried 76mm guns. However, the larger gun was only marginally more effective against a Panther's frontal armor. 7,968 Shermans with the 76mm gun were built.

vehicle.name: DUKW
vehicle.description: A truly inspirational creation, the DUKW gave Allied forces improved flexibility, especially in the Pacific. But they were also used widely in Europe, particularly in the Low Countries. More than 20,000 were built and 2,000 were sent to Britain.

vehicle.name: PzKfw B-2 ( f )
vehicle.description: The Char B-1 was the principal medium tank of the French Army in 1940. Most were destroyed or damaged during the German invasion in May-June 1940. The Germans converted 60 B1-bis tanks to carry a flamethrower in place of the hull 7.5cm gun.

vehicle.name: Motorcycle
vehicle.description: All parties in WWII used motorcycles for liaison and recon missions.

vehicle.name: Universal Carrier - 3in mor
vehicle.description: The Universal Carrier and it's variants was one of the most widely used armoured vehicles of World War II. In 1942 a Universal Carrier MkI was converted to carry a 3 in mortar, its ammunition and crew. The mortar was stowed at the back and the base plate was carried on the front of the Carrier on earlier models and on the rear later on.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 251/21 - 1,5cm Triple AA
vehicle.description: This was an SdKfz 251 m SPW boasting a triple mount of MG 151/15 AA machine guns. It entered service in August 1944 within the newly-created Panzer-Brigaden 105, 106, 107 and 108, where it provided the Panzergrenadier-battalion with low-level flak defence, but it also proved devastating against infantry and soft-skinned vehicles.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 124 - Wespe
vehicle.description: Self-propelled 10.5cm How based on a PzII chassis. First produced in Dec 1942. Only lightly armoured and open topped. Each Pz Div had an establishment of 12 Wespes.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 165 - Hummel
vehicle.description: Self-propelled 15cm How based on composite PzIII/PzIV chassis. First produced in Oct 1942. Only lightly armoured and open topped. Each Pz Div had an establishment of 6 Hummels.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 138/1 Ausf M - Grille
vehicle.description: Self-propelled 15cm Inf Gun based on PzKw 38(t) chassis. First produced in Sep 1942. Only lightly armoured and open topped. Issued to PG Regt in Pz Divs.

vehicle.name: Daimler Mk II AC
vehicle.description: Principal armoured car of British Recce Troops

vehicle.name: M5A1 Stuart
vehicle.description: Known to the British as the the Stuart VI, the M5 light tank was armed with a 37mm Gun and two 30 cal MGs. The M5 was an interim design with many improvements over the M3A1, among these being thicker armor, sloping front hull plates, and twin Cadillac engines with an automatic transmission. In early 1943 it was supplanted on the production lines by the further improved M5A1. The latter was used to replace M3A1 losses in the 1st Armored Division in North Africa, and by the time of Operation Husky in July 1943 the M5A1 had become the standard U.S. light tank. A total of 6,810 M5A1s were built.

vehicle.name: Achilles Mk IC - 17pdr SP
vehicle.description: British version of the American M10 tank destroyer but armed with a 17pdr gun. Based on an Sherman chasis.

vehicle.name: PzJg V - Jagdpanther
vehicle.description: The best all-round tank destroyer of the war. The Jagdpanther combined the Panther chassis with the 8.8cm Pak43 gun. Low silhouette, excellent sloping armour plate and the premier hard hitting "88" made it very lethal indeed. It entered combat service in February 1944.

vehicle.name: JgdPz 38(t)
vehicle.description: The JgdPz 38(t) "Hetzer" was a light tank destroyer based on the Pz 38(t) tank. Though the tank itself was obsolete by 1942, its simplicity and proven reliability kept the basic chassis in production for a variety of self-propelled guns. For the Hetzer, a modified version of the Pz IV 75mm gun was mounted in the front superstructure, and the armor on all four sides of the vehicle was sloped as much as possible. Unlike the open-topped Marder II and III, the Hetzer was completely enclosed, and its well-sloped armor and low profile greatly enhanced its survivability. It was not especially popular with its crews, however, due to its extremely cramped interior.

vehicle.name: JgdPz IV
vehicle.description: The JgdPz IV was a tank destroyer based on the PzKpfw IV chassis. It was intended as the replacement for the StuG assault gun in its anti-tank role. Its low height and sloped armor enhanced its survivability. With production occurring throughout 1944, 769 were produced. By late 1944 the JgdPz IV had been largely superseded by the JgdPz IV/70 with the more powerful gun of the Panther tank.

vehicle.name: JgdPz VI - Jagdtiger
vehicle.description: A conversion of the Tiger II hull with a massive 12.8cm Panzerjaegerkanone 44 gun fitted. The vehicle was slow and unreliable, and only a very small number were ever built. Only useful as a sort of "mobile pillobx", it was not a success in combat.

vehicle.name: Sturmmoerser - Tiger
vehicle.description: Using the chassis of a Tiger I, this bizarre vehicle mounted a 38cm rocket launcher. The Sturmtiger could only carry 14 rounds of ammunition and once fired these took ten minutes to reload with the assistance of a built-in crane mounted behind the fighting compartment.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 4/1 - Panzerwerfer 42
vehicle.description: Nebelwerfer units proved to be easy targets for counter-battery fire: the smoke trail of the rockets was a dead give-away, hence mobility was vital. The Panzerwerfer 42 mounted the 15cm Nebelwerfer onto a lightly armoured version of the Maultier halftrack.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 4 - Ammo Carrier
vehicle.description: This was the standard ammunition carrier for the Panzerwerfer 42. It was identical to this vehicle, apart for the fact that it did not mount the 15cm Nebelwerfer and had additional storage room.

vehicle.name: StuPz IV
vehicle.description: The Sturmpanzer IV was an infantry close-support AFV, especially designed for fighting in urban areas. It mounted a 15cm howitzer in a closed superstructure based on the Pz IV chassis. From May 1943 till March 1945 some 298 were built. The Sturmpanzer IV still is commonly refered to as the 'Brummbaer' (Grizzly Bear). However, this was never an official designation, and it is likely to have originated from erronous Allied intelligence reports.

vehicle.name: M16 MGMC - 50 cal Quad AA
vehicle.description: The M16 was an M3 halftrack with quad 50 cal HMGs mounted. It was lethal in the antipersonnel role.

vehicle.name: 1/4 t truck 'Jeep' - .50 cal MG
vehicle.description: Used by the US, the redoubtable Jeep was mounted with a 50 cal MG to provide greater firepower.

vehicle.name: 1/4 t truck 'Jeep' - 60mm mor
vehicle.description: Used by the US, the redoubtable Jeep was mounted with a 60mm mortar to provide some firepower to the jeep-mounted recce sections.

vehicle.name: 1/4 t truck 'Jeep' - .30 cal MG
vehicle.description: Used by the US, the redoubtable Jeep was mounted with a 30 cal MG to provide greater firepower.

vehicle.name: 2-1/2 t truck
vehicle.description: Five classes of trucks were standardized by the U.S. Army in 1939: the 1/2-ton, 1.5-ton, 2.5-ton, 4-ton, and 7.5-ton trucks. The 1/2-ton truck was later superseded by the larger 3/4-ton weapons carrier. These vehicles - many of which had 6x6 drive - were used to transport troops, weapons, equipment and supplies. The united States produced some 3.2 million soft-skin vehicles during the war. The most famous of these was the 2 1/2 ton or known as the Deuce and a half. Its greatest fame would be running supplies through France with the "Red Ball Express".

vehicle.name: 2-1/2 t truck - .50 cal MG
vehicle.description: Five classes of trucks were standardized by the U.S. Army in 1939: the 1/2-ton, 1.5-ton, 2.5-ton, 4-ton, and 7.5-ton trucks. The 1/2-ton truck was later superseded by the larger 3/4-ton weapons carrier. These vehicles - many of which had 6x6 drive - were used to transport troops, weapons, equipment and supplies. The united States produced some 3.2 million soft-skin vehicles during the war. The most famous of these was the 2 1/2 ton or known as the Deuce and a half. Its greatest fame would be during the "Red Ball Express".

vehicle.name: 4 t truck - .50 cal MG
vehicle.description: Five classes of trucks were standardized by the U.S. Army in 1939: the 1/2-ton, 1.5-ton, 2.5-ton, 4-ton, and 7.5-ton trucks. The 1/2-ton truck was later superseded by the larger 3/4-ton weapons carrier. These vehicles - many of which had 6x6 drive - were used to transport troops, weapons, equipment and supplies. The united States produced some 3.2 million soft-skin vehicles during the war.

vehicle.name: M4 Sherman - 105mm
vehicle.description: The infantry-support version of the Sherman was equipped with a 105mm howitzer, giving it poor effectiveness against tanks but making it an effective infantry close-support platform. These were used to provide heavy support in medium tank battalions, the HQ company of which was authorized an "assault gun" platoon of three Sherman 105s. Although retained in the Divisions Hq Company they were usually assigned to each of the Battalions. 4,680 Shermans were produced with a 105mm howitzer as main armament.

vehicle.name: M4A3E2 'Jumbo' - 75mm
vehicle.description: Known unofficially as the "Jumbo", the M4A3E2 was much more heavily armored than the M4. An extra 38mm of armor were added to its front and upper sides, and its lower front hull armor was 140mm thick. A new turret with 152mm-thick cast armor and a 178mm-thick gunshield replaced the standard turret. 254 Jumbos were built, all with the 75mm gun (though some were later field-modified by substituting the more powerful 76mm gun). With the intention that M4A3E2 Jumbo's would be used as true "Assault Tanks".

vehicle.name: M7 - 105mm HMC
vehicle.description: The M7 Howitzer Motor Carriage was a modified M3 Medium Tank with a 105mm howitzer carried in an open-top compartment. It first saw action in Tunisia; where it began to replace the T19 HMC Halftrack in the armored field artillery battalions of the 1st Armoured Division. Serving in batteries of six, it soon equipped all armored field artillery battalions. It proved successful in combat.

vehicle.name: M8 - 75mm HMC
vehicle.description: Based on an M5 chassis, the M8 Howitzer Motor Carriage (HMC) was used by Cavalry Assault Gun Troops for direct and indirect fire support.

vehicle.name: M21 HT - 81mm mortar
vehicle.description: Like its German equivalents the M3 proved an extremely versatile and successful vehicle which was adapted for a broad range of reconnaissance, combat, transport and support roles. More than 41,000 were built until mid-1944. This version, designated M21 mounted a standard 81mm mortar.

vehicle.name: M3A1 HT - 30 cal MG
vehicle.description: Like its German equivalents the M3 proved an extremely versatile and successful vehicle which was adapted for a broad range of reconnaissance, combat, transport and support roles. More than 41,000 were built until mid-1944.

vehicle.name: M3A1 HT - 2 x 30 cal MG
vehicle.description: Like its German equivalents the M3 proved an extremely versatile and successful vehicle which was adapted for a broad range of reconnaissance, combat, transport and support roles. More than 41,000 were built until mid-1944.

vehicle.name: M3A1 HT - 50 cal MG
vehicle.description: Like its German equivalents the M3 proved an extremely versatile and successful vehicle which was adapted for a broad range of reconnaissance, combat, transport and support roles. More than 41,000 were built until mid-1944.

vehicle.name: M3A1 HT
vehicle.description: Like its German equivalents the M3 proved an extremely versatile and successful vehicle which was adapted for a broad range of reconnaissance, combat, transport and support roles. More than 41,000 were built until mid-1944.

vehicle.name: M20 AUC - .50 cal MG
vehicle.description: Designed for use as a command car and AA vehicle for TD battalions, this was an M8 with the turret removed and space for additional personnel and radios.

vehicle.name: M10 TD - 76mm GMC
vehicle.description: Nicknamed The Wolverine, the M10 Gun Motor Carriage was based on the M4A2 Medium Tank, but to give the tank destroyer greater mobility its armor was thinner. It also had a new turret, which was open-topped to increase visibility. Because the 3-inch AA gun was so large and heavy, two 1800-lb. counterweights were attached to the rear of the turret to keep it balanced. Moreover, the heavy turret lacked power traverse. After the M10 GMC's successful debut in Tunisia, where it equipped the 899th and 776th Tank Destroyer Battalions, it replaced the M3 GMC halftrack and became the standard U.S. tank destroyer until late 1944 when the M18 and M36 began to replace it. A total of 4,993 M10s were bui

vehicle.name: M18 TD - 76mm GMC
vehicle.description: Nicknamed The Hellcat, the M18 Gun Motor Carriage was designed to be very light and fast, and proved to be the fastest tracked vehicle of the war. It was popular with its crews, because its speed allowed it to quickly change positions during a battle. This tank destroyer could have been deployed in 1943, but commanders in Europe wanted to wait for the more heavily armed M36 which was in the final stages of production. 2,507 M18s were built.

vehicle.name: M36 TD - 90mm GMC
vehicle.description: Referred to as the Jackson or Slugger, the M36 Gun Motor Carriage was essentially an M10A1 GMC with a new (but still open-topped) turret and a powerful 90mm gun. Because of this firepower, it was the most successful of all the U.S. tank destroyers. Unfortunately, many commanders expected to use this vehicle in the battlefield as a tank - a task for which it was not well suited, with its open top and thinner armor. The realization that real tanks were more adaptable in a fast-changing battle ultimately led to the end of the Tank Destroyer Command in 1946. 1,413 M36 GMCs were produced.

vehicle.name: M15 MGMC - 37mm/50cal AA
vehicle.description: The M15 was an M3 halftrack with two 50 cal HMGs and a 37mm AA gun in a single combined mount. It predated the M16 and some were still in service at the time of the Bulge offensive.

vehicle.name: M12 - 155mm HMC
vehicle.description: Sometimes called "King Kong", the M12 Gun Motor Carriage was an M1917 or M1918 155mm gun mounted on a heavily modified M3 Medium Tank chassis. Seventy-four of the one hundred built were sent to Normandy between June and August of 1944. As the only heavy artillery that could keep pace with the rapid advance across France after American forces broke out of the hedgerows, this vehicle proved especially valuable. This gun was used in batteries of four.

vehicle.name: M30 - Cargo Carrier
vehicle.description: Based on the M3 tank chassis, this was identical to the M12 GMC with the gun was removed. It was used to transport crew and ammunition for the M12.

vehicle.name: T17 Staghound AC
vehicle.description: Produced by Cheverolet but used by the British an CW after the US adopted the lighter M8 Greyhound vehicle instead.The Staghound first saw operational service in Italy, where many units found its large physical size too restrictive in the narrow roads and streets of Europe. As a result it saw most service at squadron and regimental headquarter level

vehicle.name: M3 (T12) HT - 75mm GMC
vehicle.description: This M3 halftrack mounting an M1897A4 field gun was designed as an interim tank destroyer pending the arrival of the M10 GMC. As such, the M3 provided mixed results in Tunisia. Its thin armor allowed it to be easily destroyed, but it was effective against German armor when used properly from ambush positions. A total of 2,202 were built, but 1,360 later had their big gun removed and served as M3A1 halftracks.

vehicle.name: FlakPz IV Moebelwagen
vehicle.description: An interim design intended to fill in for more advanced flak tanks, the Moebelwagen mounted a 3.7cm Flak gun on an PzKw IV chassis. These were issued to Pz Divs stationed on the Western Front and proved adequate in combat.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 124 - Ammo Carrier
vehicle.description: This was the Wespe with its gun removed to serve as a dedicated ammo carrier.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 165 - Ammo Carrier
vehicle.description: Hummel with the gun removed to carry cargo.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 251/16 - Flamethrowers
vehicle.description: This version of the SdKfz 251, the 'mittlerer Flammpanzerwagen', mounted a pair of heavy flamethrowers, one to each side of the vehicle. It was fielded by the Pionier companies of the Panzergrenadier regiments.

vehicle.name: PzKfw 35-S 739 ( f )
vehicle.description: The Germans regarded the Somua S-35 as the best of the French tanks they had fought in 1940. Several hundred were passed to Italy and subsequently taken over by the Germans after the surrender of that country; others were taken directly into German service.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 251/3 - Radio
vehicle.description: The SdKfz 251/3 traded personnel transport capacity for extra radio equipment, making it the (company) command version of the m.SPW.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 251/11 - Field Phone
vehicle.description: The 'mittlerer Fernsprecherwagen' was the telephone cable-laying version of the SdKfz 251.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 250/3 - Radio
vehicle.description: Command version of the Sd.Kfz.250, equipping the Coy HQ of the 2. Kp./ Pz.Aufkl.Abt.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 250/5 - Observation
vehicle.description: The le. Beob.Pz.SS. was the scout car version of the Sd.Kfz.250, equipped with extra radio equipment and scissor binoculars. In theory, it was to equip the second company of the Pz.Aufkl.Abt., where it was to be protected by the Sd.Kfz.250/9.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 250/7 - 8cm mortar
vehicle.description: The Sd.Kfz.250/7 mounted a GrW 34 81mm mortar that could be fired from the vehicle. It equipped the heavy platoon within the Rifle Companies of the Pz.Aufkl.Abt and some SS Panzergrenadier Companies.

vehicle.name: StuG IV
vehicle.description: The StuG IV used the Panzerkampfwagen IV chassis in combination with a slightly modified StuG III superstructure. Issued mainly to infantry divisions, they became known as a very effective anti-tank vehicle. 1,108 were built from December 1943 to May 1945. An additional 31 were constructed from salvaged Panzer IV hulls.

vehicle.name: StuH 42
vehicle.description: The StuH 42 assault gun was based on the StuG IIIG. The StuH was created in answer to requests from the front for a vehicle with more anti-personnel firepower than currently available with the 75mm cannon. The extra firepower was gained by installing a 105mm howitzer. Other than the bigger gun, the StuH was more or less identical to the StuG IIIG. Around 1200 units were constructed by the end of the war.

vehicle.name: FlakPz 38(t)
vehicle.description: The FlaKPz 38(t) was an anti-aircraft tank developed in late 1943 as an interim solution to the lack of full-tracked AA vehicles. It carried a 20mm FlaK 38 on a modified Marder III Ausf M chassis. The single 20mm gun was lacking in firepower, but the vehicle was needed until more heavily armed AA tanks could be produced. Constructed from late 1943 until early 1944, around 140 were built. They were assigned to the AA platoons in panzer regiments.

vehicle.name: Pz IV/70 (A)
vehicle.description: The Pz IV 70 (A) was a stopgap solution. In order to gain production time, the Alkett firm mounted the L/70 gun into a Jagdpanzer superstructure fit directly onto the unmodified Panzer IV chassis. This made for a higher and more 'top-heavy' AFV than the Pz IV/70(V) produced by Vomag. Some 278 were produced from August 1944 till March 1945. Its higher superstructure made it tactically less suited for the 'tank-hunter' rôle. This, together with the fact that it shared many components with the Panzer IV, resulted in the vehicle being considered more as an upgunned medium tank, than a pure tank destroyer.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 251/7 - Engineer
vehicle.description: The SdKfz 251/7 was the specialised 'mittlerer Pionierpanzerwagen'. It had extra storage room for all kinds of equipment and on its sides it carried two assault bridges.

vehicle.name: m PKW - car
vehicle.description: The German Army fielded many different medium car types (m.PKW - mittlerer Personenkraftwagen), of both military and civilian origin, and both with and without cross-country capacities.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 251/8 - Ambulance
vehicle.description: The armoured ambulance ('mittlerer Krankenpanzerwagen') was used within armoured units.

vehicle.name: Bicycle
vehicle.description: The German Army had been using bicycles during the entire war, but by 1944 the growing shortages in motorised transport vehicles and fuel meant that a growing number of previously motorised battalions had to swap their motor transport for bicycles.

vehicle.name: Motorcycle with sidecar
vehicle.description: The motorcycles with sidecar was a standard asset of the German Army of WWII. When fully-equipped, some of the heavier versions could weigh up to half a ton.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 234/3 - 7.5cm gun
vehicle.description: Within the SdKfz 234 armoured car series, the SdKfz 234/3 was there to provide heavy fire support. Its 7.5cm L/24 gun, mounted in an open-topped fixed superstructure, had started the war as the main gun of the Panzer IV...

vehicle.name: SdKfz 3 - Maultier 2 t
vehicle.description: In the harsh conditions on the Eastern Front, wheeled trucks often proved useless. As a solution, the 'Maultiere' (mules) were developed, trucks converted into halftracks.

vehicle.name: RSO - prime mover
vehicle.description: The RSO - 'Raupenschlepper Ost' was the answer to the harsh road conditions on the Eastern Front. A fully-tracked tractor, it was to prove less prone to damage than the over-engineered halftrack series. Its big handicap however, was its low speed.

vehicle.name: M8 - 37mm gun - .30 cal MG
vehicle.description: The M8 Light Armored Car served as the primary AFV in mechanized cavalry units, replacing the M3A1 Scout Car and the M2 Halftrack. Although it was lightly armored and undergunned, its crews liked its speed and the cross-country mobility provided by its light weight and 6x6 drive.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 138 - Marder III M
vehicle.description: Ausf M was the final variant of the Marder series and was a significant improvement over previous models, with its lower silhouette, sloped armour and much more functional fighting compartment.

vehicle.name: M24 Chaffee
vehicle.description: Commonly referred to as the "Chaffee" in honor of Gen. Adna Chaffee, the "Father of the U.S. Armored Force", this tank was designed to replace the M5A1. It was based on the M18 tank destroyer but had a new turret with a light-weight 75mm gun from the B-25H Mitchell Bomber. In 1944 and 1945, a total of 4195 were built.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 250/7 - Ammo Carrier
vehicle.description: The SdKfz 250 was the second APC to be developed. It was used mainly by reconnaissance units and as a command vehicle. Some 7,500 were built.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 250/2 - Field Phone
vehicle.description: The 250 was the second APC to be developed. It was used mainly by reconnaissance units and as a command vehicle. Some 7,500 were built.

vehicle.name: 0.5 t Horse-drawn Wagon
vehicle.description: The specifications for the 0.5 t Horse-drawn Wagon are based on the German Hf 3 small field wagon series. Towed by one or, when available, two horses.

vehicle.name: 0.75 t Horse-drawn Wagon
vehicle.description: The specifications for the 0.75 t Horse-drawn Wagon are based on the German Hf 1 light field wagon series, but are also representative of all similar kinds of wagons, such as the captured Central and Eastern European Panjewagen (Pleskau), which were widely used by the German Army, or the Ersatz-Feldwagen 43. It was towed by two horses.

vehicle.name: 1 t Horse-drawn Wagon
vehicle.description: The specifications for the 1 t Horse-drawn Wagon are based on the German Hf 2 heavy field wagon series, which was towed by four horses.

vehicle.name: Infantry cart
vehicle.description: The specifications for the infantry cart are based on the German If 8 small infantry cart. It could either be towed by two men or one horse, and in the latter case, two carts were often linked one behind another.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 250/11 - 2.8cm AT
vehicle.description: This combination of the 2.8cm sPzB 41 on the SdKfz 250 chassis was an equivalent to the SdKfz 250/10. It did not feature in the theoretical establishments of 1944.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 232 - 2cm gun
vehicle.description: The SdKfz 232 eight-wheeled armoured car was the predecessor of the SdKfz 234/1. By late 1944, some were still in service.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 233 - 7.5cm gun
vehicle.description: The SdKfz 233 mounted the 7.5cm L/24 gun in an open-topped fixed superstructure. It provided heavy armoured car companies with heavy fire support. Though supplanted by the SdKfz 234/3 in 1944, surviving vehicles remained in action.

vehicle.name: Motor Scooter
vehicle.description: Allied paratroopers used scooters to maintain contact between units, increase their mobility and haul small loads. The Cushman Motor Works Model 53 Airborne Scooter was airdropped by parachute or carried by glider, and it had a hitch to pull a model M3A4 general-purpose utility cart.

vehicle.name: s PKW - car
vehicle.description: The German Army fielded many different heavy car types (s.PKW - schwerer Personenkraftwagen), of both military and civilian origin, and both with and without cross-country capacities.

vehicle.name: Kraftomnibus
vehicle.description: In Headquarter units, the German Army made use of various types of buses (Bussing - NAG, Mercedes and Opel...) to transport staff personnel in more comfortable conditions.

vehicle.name: Armored 1/4 t truck 'Jeep' - .50 cal MG
vehicle.description: Field modification to provide Jeep-borne recon troops with a little more protection.

vehicle.name: Armored 1/4 t truck 'Jeep' - .30 cal MG
vehicle.description: Field modification to provide Jeep-borne recon troops with a little more protection.

vehicle.name: LKW 4.5 t - 3.7cm Flak
vehicle.description: To increase mobility and speed of reaction, lighter Flak guns were mounted onto trucks with armoured driver cabins. This version combined the 3.7cm Flak gun with the 4.5t cross-country truck.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 222 - 2cm gun
vehicle.description: The SdKfz 222 four-wheeled armoured car was the main armoured car early in the War. On the Eastern Front its cross-country capacities proved insufficient, and from late 1943 on it was to be replaced by the SdKfz 250/9 half-track, which had the same 2cm gun-turret, the so-called 'Hangelafette' ('Hanging Cradle'). By late 1944, some SdKfz 222 were still in service.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 223 - Radio
vehicle.description: The SdKfz 223 four-wheeled armoured car was similar to the SdKfz 222, except that it traded the 2cm gun for increased space for radio equipment. The SdKfz 223 was the actual scouting vehicle, while the SdKfz 222 acted as its escort. By late 1944, some SdKfz 223 were still in service, but the heavier armoured cars along with the SdKfz 251/3 and 250/3 had taken over its rôle.

vehicle.name: SdKfz 164 - Nashorn
vehicle.description: The Nashorn was a self-propelled 88mm AT-Gun based on composite PzIII/PzIV chassis, entering service in mid 1943. It was only lightly armoured and open topped, and served in Army independant Panzerjäger battalions.

vehicle.name: Flamm-Pz 38(t)
vehicle.description: 20 Hetzers were converted into flamethrowers in late 1944 for use in the Ardennes Offensive. The flame projector was the 14mm Flammenwerfer 41 and was fitted in the standard barrel in order to conceal its real role.

vehicle.name: LKW 2 t - tanker truck
vehicle.description: The German Army was always short on standardised transport. The 2t class of trucks included all lighter truck types with a loading capacity of about 2 tons. For BFTB, abstraction was made of the difference in trucks with and without cross-country capacities.

vehicle.name: Kangaroo
vehicle.description: This vehicle represents the M7 Howitzer Motor Carriage with the gun removed and converted to an armoured personnel carrier. This vehicle also represents the similar use of the Canadian 'Ram' tank. The kangaroo was used mainly by Canadian mechanized troops as a fully tracked carrier. It proved to be quite successful and was used throughout the campaign in northwest Europe.
